Name: Standing Isis, wings reaching downwards
Description: Apart from being the mother goddess per se, Isis was also a protective deity, as illustrated by this statuette. She is attached to a thin base with a tenon. On her head she is wearing cow's horns, a sun disc on a kalathos, and a striated wig with a uraeus on her forehead. Her winged arms are spread out obliquely. The feathers on the outside are rendered by dots (flight feathers) and stripes (wing feathers). The bird's plumage is depicted on her back like scales; a broad, short tail has been carved on her buttocks.
